_header: When that April with his showers soot
Note:
For individual [verse] Tales and links see: the General Prologue
(6415), Knight’s Tale
(6530), Miller’s Prologue
(6427), Miller’s Tale
(6537), Reeve’s Prologue
(6307), Reeve’s Tale
(724), Cook’s Prologue
(5238), Cook’s Tale
(145), Introduction to the Man of Law’s Tale
(4315), Man of Law’s Prologue
(3929), Man of Law’s Tale
(2587), ‘Man of Law’s Endlink’ (4316), Wife of Bath’s Prologue
(1242), Wife of Bath’s Tale
(2618), Friar’s Prologue
(5802), Friar’s Tale
(6536), Summoner’s Prologue
(5756), Summoner’s Tale
3255, Clerk’s Prologue
(4860), Clerk’s Tale
(5573), ‘Clerk’s Endlink’ (5801), Merchant’s Prologue
(6185), Merchant’s Tale
(6535), ‘Merchant’s Endlink’ (745), ‘Squire’s Headlink’ (5024), Squire’s Tale
(725), ‘Squire-Franklin link’ (2499), Franklin’s Prologue
(5617), Franklin’s Tale
(2476), Physician’s Tale
(5599), ‘Physician-Pardoner link’ (4314), Pardoner’s Prologue
(3251), Pardoner’s Tale
(2502), Shipman’s Tale
(120), ‘Shipman-Prioress link’ (6206), Prioress’s Prologue
(3970), Prioress’s Tale
(5601), Prologue to Sir Thopas
(6401), Sir Thopas
(3097), ‘Thopas-Melibee link’ (3700), Monk’s Prologue
(6295), Monk’s Tale
(2316), Nun’s Priest’s Prologue
(2033), Nun’s Priest’s Tale
(142), ‘Nun’s Priest’s Epilogue’ (4870), Prologue of the Second Nun’s Tale
(5405), Second Nun’s Tale
(5729.4), Canon’s Yeoman’s Prologue
(6296), Canon’s Yeoman’s Tale
(6753), Manciple’s Prologue
(6711), Manciple’s Tale
(6390), Parson’s Prologue
(941); for the Tale of Gamelyn, see 3090. For the Tale of Beryn, see 6270. For two texts sometimes referred to as the Plowman’s Tale, see 5277 and 6603. For an edition based on San Marino, CA, Henry Huntington Library EL 26.C.9 [‘Ellesmere’], but that incorporates numerous readings from other MSS, see Benson (1987)
XBenson, Larry Dean. The Riverside Chaucer. 3rd ed. Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1987, 123-328.
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Canterbury Tales — ten fragments in various rhyme schemes; Prologue, frame, and most tales in couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
Whan that Apprill with his shouris sooteThe drought of Marche hath
                    pershid to the roote…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…beth fructuous & that in litel spaceand to do wel god
                    send yow his grace
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
Here bigynneth the prolog of this book the which is namede the talis of
                    Caunturbury in the whiche prolog thauthour openly declarith the names of alle
                    the pilgremes there condiciouns & there array (f. 4)

BodBar20.First Lines:
…That swiche a lewed mannes witte shal paceThe wisdom of an
                    hepe of lerned men…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…W[her?]so þou come among high or loweKe[pe?] wel þy
                    tong and þenke vpon þe crowe

Bod414.First Lines:
Whan that April with his shouris soteThe drought of March hath
                    percid to þe Rote…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and that in litle spaceAnd to do wele god send
                    you his grace

Bod686.First Lines:
Whan that april with his showres swoteThe drouth of March hath
                    perced the rote…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…In which into þis day in noble wyseMen don to Crist and
                    to his seint seruise
Bod686.Note: Incomplete; ends with the Second Nun’s Tale.

BodDoud4.First Lines:
…Þ had bot lytell golde in coffreBut all þat he
                    myght of his frendys hente…
BodDoud4.Last Lines:
But alle with siluer wrought full clene and wellTheire girdelis and
                    theire pouchis euerydeell

BodHatDon1.First Lines:
Whan that Aprill with his showres swoteThe drought of Marche hath
                    perced þe rote…
BodHatDon1.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuose and that litul spaceAnd to done wele god sende
                    yow his grace

BodLauMis600.First Lines:
That in hir cuppe was no ferthing
                    seene…
BodLauMis600.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and þat in litil spaceAnd to do wel god
                    sende you grace

BodLauMis739.First Lines:
[W]hanne that aueryll wyth hys schoures soteThe droghte of marche
                    had perced vnto rote…
BodLauMis739.Last Lines:
…ffull strong hit was of plateAnd ouer that his cote
                    armure

BodRawPoe141.First Lines:
Bi ordynaunce thrugh out the cyte largeHonged with cloth of gold
                    & not with sarge…
BodRawPoe141.Last Lines:
…Now had this Phebus in his hous a wyfWheche that he loued
                    more than his lyf
BodRawPoe141.Note:
Contains I.2567-IX.140. Catchwords on p. 436: ‘And nyght &
                    day’.
BodRawPoe141.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Clerk’s Tale, a Six-Text Print from 6 MSS not containing the
                Pardoner’s Tale.
The Chaucer Society
         Series 1, no. 92. London: Trübner, 1899.

BodRawPoe149.First Lines:
Olde ypocras holy and galyeneSerapion rafi and
                    auysene…
BodRawPoe149.Last Lines:
…Bethe fructuouse and that in litil spaceAnd to do wel god
                    sende yow his grace
BodRawPoe149.Note:
I.431-X.1092. Verse ends on f. 122. On f. 136v is the
                    colophon: ‘Expliciunt fabula script[us?] per snnevets mlliW’
                    (mirror writing for William Stevenns.

BodRawPoe223.First Lines:
There as this lord was keper of the selleThe rule of seint Maure or
                    of seint Beneit…
BodRawPoe223.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and that in litil spaceAnd to do wel god send
                    you his grace

OxfChrCh152.First Lines:
Whan that Auerell with his shoures sooteThe droght of Marche hath
                    perced to the roote…
OxfChrCh152.Last Lines:
…Beeth fructious and that in litel spaceAnd to do wele god
                    send yow his grace
OxfChrCh152.Note:
Missing VIII.627-719; X.887-943; X.1044-1092 due to loss of leaves.
                    Verse ends on f. 249v.

OxfCCC198.First Lines:
…ffor to telle ȝow of his arrayhis hors were goode but
                    he was not gay…
OxfCCC198.Last Lines:
…That I wol stonde to correcciounvppon þis word we han
                    assented sone
OxfCCC198.Facsimiles:
“Digital
                    Facsimile of Corpus Christi, Oxford MS 198 of the Canterbury
            Tales”  .

OxfNew314.First Lines:
…fforto be wise in byinge of vitailffor wheþir he paide
                    or took be tailAlgate he waitid so on his acateThat he was ay before
                    & in good state…
OxfNew314.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuos and þat in litil spaceAnd to do wel god
                    sende you his grace
OxfNew314.Note:
Two leaves missing at beginning, so begins I.569; verse ends
                        265v; prose ends 311v.
OxfNew314.Attributed Title:
Explicit tractatus Galfridi Chaucer de gestis peregrinorum versus
                        Cantuarium (f. 311v)

OxfTri49.First Lines:
When that Aperil with his shouris swotethe drought of Marche hath
                    percid the rote…
OxfTri49.Last Lines:
…bithe fructuous and that in litil spaceand to do well god
                    sende you his grace

CULDd424.First Lines:
…though a wydewe had nouȝt a shooSo plesant was his In
                    PrincipioȜet wold he haue a ferthyng or he wentHis purchas was
                    wel betir than his rent…
CULDd424.Last Lines:
…Of watres corosif and of lymailAnd of bodies
                    mollificacionAnd also of here induracion…
CULDd424.Note:
I.253-VIII.855. The scribe writes ‘Quod  Wytton’ and ‘Amen quod Wytton’ at the ends of the
                        Knight’s Tale, Miller’s Tale, Man of
                        Law’s Tale, and Summoner’s Tale (ff. 39, fol. 47, 67,
                    and 92).
CULDd424.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Cambridge MS. Dd.4.24 of Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales,
                Completed by the Egerton MS. 2726 (The Haistwell MS).
The Chaucer Society
         1st Series, no. 95 (Part 1, issue for 1901) and 96 (Part 2, issue for
            1902).

CULGg427.First Lines:
…Me thynketh it acordaunt to resounTo telle ȝow al the
                        conchusyoun
condition…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…Or art a Persoun sey soth by thyn feyBe what thow be ne breke
                    thow nat oure pley…
CULGg427.Note:
Folios 127-131 missing so begins imperfectly; these supplied by two
                        17th-century hands copying from Speght’s 1598 edition onto
                    folios 10-28v; verse ends 398v but prose ends
                        443v with ‘here takyt the makere of this bok his
                    leue.’ Begins I.37.
CULGg427.Facsimiles:
Parkes,  Malcolm B.,  and  Richard Beadle.  
             “Introduction.” 
             Poetical Works. Geoffrey Chaucer. A Facsimile of Cambridge University
                Library MS Gg.4.27. 3 vols Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1979 (vol. 1); 1980 (vols. 2-3).
CULGg427.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James. 
             The Cambridge MS (University Library, Gg.4.27) of Chaucer’s
                Canterbury Tales.
Chaucer Society
         Series 1, nos. 4, 10, 17, 28, 33, 40, 52, 66. London: Trübner,
            1868-79.

CULIi326.First Lines:
…And euermore he hadde the souereyn prisAnd though that he
                    was war he was wise…
CULIi326.Last Lines:
…Bethe fructuouse and that in litle spaceAnd forto do wele god
                    sende vs grace
CULIi326.Note:
Begins I.67, and missing text supplied by a later hand in top nad right
                    margin of f. 2; verse ends f. 224, prose ends f. 237.
CULIi326.Attributed Author:
Explicit Liber Galfridi Chawcer de gestis Peregrinorum versus
                        Cantuarium (f. 237)
CULIi326.Attributed Title:
Explicit Liber Galfridi Chawcer de gestis Peregrinorum versus
                        Cantuarium (f. 237)

CULMm25.First Lines:
…Syngynge he was or floytynge alle þe dayeHe was as
                    fresshe as is þe moneth of Maye…
CULMm25.Last Lines:
…Beeth fructuous and þat in litell spaceAnd to do wele
                    god sende us his grace

CamFitzMc181.First Lines:
[W]Han that Aprile with his schoures sooteThe drouthe of marche
                    hathe persed þe rote…
CamFitzMc181.Last Lines:
…Telle quod he your meditacounAnd hasteth you þe sonne
                    goth a doun
CamFitzMc181.Note:
Verse ends on f. 267v at X.70, with a catchphrase for the
                    first line of the Parson’s Tale.
CamFitzMc181.Attributed Author:
Here bigynneth the Talys of Caunterbiry / Compiled by Geffrei Chaucers (f.
                    1)
CamFitzMc181.Attributed Title:
Here bigynneth the Talys of Caunterbiry / Compiled by Geffrei Chaucers (f.
                    1)

CamTCC582.First Lines:
Whan that Aprille with his shoures sooteThe drouȝt of Marche
                    hath perced to the rooteAnd bathed eueri veyne in such licoureOf wich
                    vertu engendred is the floure…
CamTCC582.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and that in litil spaceAnd to do well god
                    sende you his grace
CamTCC582.Note: Ends X.880. Verse ends. on f. 118.

CamTCC595.First Lines:
…In granade at the siege eke had he beIn algreth had he ryden
                    and in belmarye…
CamTCC595.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and that in litil spaceAnd to do wel god sende
                    you his grace
CamTCC595.Note:
Begins I.56; lines 1-55 supplied by a later (sixteenth-century) hand on
                    ff. 3v-4v. Verse ends on f. 277v.

BLAdd5140.First Lines:
Whan that Aprylle wyth hys showres sooteThe drowhte of Marche hath
                    percede to the rote…
BLAdd5140.Last Lines:
…Beeth fructuous and that in litil spaceAnd to do wel god send
                    you his grace
BLAdd5140.Attributed Author:
Explicit prohemium Rectoris Incipit narracio eiusdem et est ultima de
                        hijs quas Chauncer composuit (f. 314)

BLAdd10340.First Lines:
Þere was a pore person of a touneAnd was a goode man of
                    religioune…
BLAdd10340.Last Lines:
…But cristes lore & hys apostles tweluehe tauȝt but
                    first he folwed it hym selue

BLAdd25718.First Lines: …Now trewly how sore that me smerte…
BLAdd25718.Last Lines: …Helpe me to telle hit in thin reuerence…
BLAdd25718.Note:
Contains lines I.1394-1524, 1584-1706, 1829-1950, 2011-3108; 3109-3486;
                    II.31-517, 702-822; III.1891-2294; Fragment VI; IV.1-1013; VII.303-452,
                    VII.453-473 (474-523 are partially present on a very damaged folio), 1256-1564
                    (with missing leaves taking 1311-1316; 1371-1538).

BLAdd35286.First Lines:
…But sykerly she hadde a fair forheed It was almost a spanne
                    brood y trowe…
BLAdd35286.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and that in litel spaceAnd to do wel god sende
                    yow his grace
BLAdd35286.Note: Contains lines I.154-X.472. Verse ends on f. 229.
BLAdd35286.Editions:
Horobin,  Simon. 
             “A Transcription and Study of British Library MS Additional 35286 of
                Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales.” 
         Diss. Univ. of Sheffield, 1997.

BLEge2726.First Lines:
Whan that Aprill with his shoures sooteThe drought of Marche hath
                    pershed þe roote…
BLEge2726.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and þat in litle spaceAnd to do wele god
                    send yow his grace
BLEge2726.Note:
Ends at X.1084, with the missing text supplied on an eighteenth-century
                    leaf. Verse ends. f. 261v.
BLEge2726.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Cambridge MS. Dd.4.24 of Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales,
                Completed by the Egerton MS. 2726 (The Haistwell MS).
The Chaucer Society
         1st Series, no. 95 (Part 1, issue for 1901) and 96 (Part 2, issue for
            1902).

BLEge2863.First Lines:
…Or who haþ ȝow mysboden or offendidAnd telleth me
                    ȝif it may be amended…
BLEge2863.Last Lines:
…I take but the sentence trusteth wellTherefore I make
                    protestacioun…
BLEge2863.Note:
Begins at I.909 and ends X.937, with losses elsewhere. Verse ends on f.
                        186v with X.59.

BLEge2864.First Lines:
[W]han that Aprille with his showres sooteThe drowhte of marche
                    hath perced to the roote…
BLEge2864.Last Lines:
…Beeth fructuous and that in litil spaceAnd to do weel god
                    send you his grace Amen
BLEge2864.Attributed Author:
Incipit liber Galstid Chaucer de gestis peregrinorum versus
                        Cantuariam (f. 1)
BLEge2864.Attributed Title:
Incipit liber Galstid Chaucer de gestis peregrinorum versus
                        Cantuariam (f. 1)

BLHar1239.First Lines:
…Thys duke of qwhom I make mencyounWhan he was all most comyn
                    to the towne…
BLHar1239.Last Lines:
…Wych was þe most gentyl thynkys ȝowNow tel me or
                    þat þe forthere rideI can no more my tale is at
                    Anende
BLHar1239.Note:
Begins I.893; ends V.1624, followed by a colophon:‘Vestre
                        magnifice & generosissime dominacionis humilimus seruiens& ser
                        Orate heremita de Grenewych mundo quasi totalitersegregatus ac mentibus
                        suorum fortune amicorum & hominum
                    peroblitus’.

BLHar1758.First Lines:
Whan that Aprill with his schoures swoteThe drought of Marche hath
                    perced to þe rote…
BLHar1758.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous & that in litell spaceAnd to do well god
                    sende you his grace
BLHar1758.Note: The Parson’s Prologue ends on f. 205.
BLHar1758.Attributed Author:
[H]Ere begynneth the book of tales of Caunterburye compiled by Gef / fraie
                    Chaucers of Brytayne chef poete (f. 1)
BLHar1758.Attributed Title:
[H]Ere begynneth the book of tales of Caunterburye compiled by Gef / fraie
                    Chaucers of Brytayne chef poete (f. 1); Prologus libri (RT)

BLHar7333.First Lines:
Whanne þat Aperyll with his shoures swooteÞe Drowght of
                    marche hathe perced to þe rote…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuos and that in litle spaceAnd to do wel god sende
                    you his grace
BLHar7333.Note: The Parson’s Prologue ends on f. 116.
BLHar7333.Attributed Title:
On f. 37, the poem is introduced as ‘The Prologue of the Knyghtes
                    Tale’, followed by the heading: ‘O yee so noble and worthi pryncis
                    and princesse oþer estatis or degrees. what euer yee beo þat haue
                    disposicione or plesaunce. to rede or here þe stories of olde tymis passed
                    to kepe yow frome ydelnesse and slowþe. in escheuing oþer folies
                    þat might be cause of more harome filowyng vowcheth sauf I be seche yowe.
                    to fynde yowe occupacioun in þe Reding here of þe tales of
                    Caunterburye wiche beon compilid in þis boke filowyng ffirst foundid
                    ymagenid and made boþe for disporte and leornyng of all þoo that beon
                    gentile of birthe or of condiciouns by þe laureal and moste famous poete
                    þat euer was to fore him as in þemvelisshing of oure rude moders
                    englisshe tonge. clepid Chaucyer a Gavfrede of whos soule god for his mercy have
                    pitee of his grace Amen’.

BLHar7334.First Lines:
WHan that aprille with his schowres swooteThe drought of Marche
                    haþ perced to þe roote…
BLHar7334.Last Lines:
…Beþ fructuous and þat in litil spaceAnd to do wel
                    God sende ȝow grace
BLHar7334.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Harleian MS 7334 of Chaucer’s ‘Canterbury
                Tales’.
Chaucer Society
         73. London: Trübner, 1885.

BLHar7335.First Lines:
…Duk Perotheus loued wel ArciteAnd had him knowe at thebes
                    yeer by yere…
BLHar7335.Last Lines:
…Ther cam a priue theef men clepen dethThat in this contre al
                    the peple sleth

BLLan851.First Lines:
Whan þat Aprill wyþe his schoures sooteþe drought of
                    Marche haþe perced to þe roote…
BLLan851.Last Lines:
…Beþ fructuous & þat in litel spaceAnd to do
                    wele god send ȝowe his grace
BLLan851.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,

             The Lansdowne Manuscript of Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales.
Chaucer Society
         Series 1, nos. 7, 13, 20, 36, 43, 55, 69. London: Trübner,
            1868-79.

BLRoy17Dxv.First Lines:
And of his porte As Meke as is a MaydeHe neuer yett no villanye ne
                    sayde…
BLRoy17Dxv.Note:
Contains I.69-X.449, with the last folios being badly damaged. Verse
                    ends on f. 290v.

BLRoy18Cii.First Lines:
WHan that Aprill wit his shoures sooteThe drought of
                    marche hath perced to þe roote…
BLRoy18Cii.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and þat in litel spaceAnd to do wel god
                    send ȝow his grace
BLRoy18Cii.Attributed Title:
Here endeth the book of the tales of Caunterburye compiled by Geffrey
                    Chaucer of whos soule Ihesu Crist haue mercy Amen (f. 271)

BLSl1685.First Lines:
He wolde suffre for a quart of wyneA good felowe to haue his
                    concubyne…
BLSl1685.Last Lines:
…But sir I dyd it nouȝt in no wicked ententeCometh doune
                    & I shalle telle you what I ment
BLSl1685.Note:
Contains I.649-VII.3424. Catchwords on f. 222v: ‘I
                    shalle’.

BLSl1686.First Lines:
In lystes thries and aye slayne his fooThis ilke worthy knyght had
                    be also…
BLSl1686.Last Lines:
…Where so thou come amonges high or loweKepe wele thy tunge
                    and thinke on the crowe

NLW21972D.Last Lines:
Yis Sire quod [ ] þis hoost s[ ] mote I goBut I be mery ywis I
                    wil be blamedAnd right anoon his tale he hath attamedAnd thus he said
                    vnto vs euerychonThis swete preest this goodly man Sire Iohn
NLW21972D.Note:
Three damaged leaves containing: VII.2784-2820; VII.2822-2860;
                    VII.3021-3058; VII.3060-3098; VII 3184-3222; VII.3223-3262.

         Leicester, England: Scholarly Digital Editions, 2000.

                        ed.  
             The Hengwrt Chaucer Digital Facsimile (CD-ROM).
         Leicester, England: Scholarly Digital Editions, 2000: Contains a digital facsimile and transcription of the
                        Merthyr Fragments.

Alnwick455.First Lines:
fful fetouse was hir cloke as I was wareOf smale corall a
                    bouȝt hir arme she bare…
Alnwick455.Last Lines:
…Be fructuouse and þat in litill spaseAnd to do wele God
                    send ȝew his grase
Alnwick455.Note:
Contains I.157-X.989 plus the Tale of Beryn (6270). Verse ends on f.
                        286v.
Alnwick455.Editions:
Bowers,  John M.,
                        ed.  
             The Canterbury Tales:
                    Fifteenth-Century Continuations and Additions.
         Kalamazoo, MI: Medieval Institute Publications, 1992: 55-200.

Chats.First Lines:
…Now ladie bright to whom all wofull crienÞou glorie of
                    womanhed þu faire may…
Chats.Last Lines:
…Send me no more vn to non hethenesBot þank my lord here
                    of hys kyndnes…
Chats.Note:
Two fragments of the Man of Law’s Tale: II.850-924;
                    1076-1144.

GULHun197.First Lines:
…His table dormaunt in his halle alweyeStode redy couered all
                    the long daye…
GULHun197.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and þat in litel spaceAnd to do weel god
                    sende you his grace
GULHun197.Note:
Begins I.353. On f. 102v is a scribal colophon:
                        ‘Orate pro salute animarum Galfridi Spirleng Ciuis Norwici Courtholder Clerici Maioratus & comitatus dicte
                        Ciuitatis ac Thome Spirleng filij sui qui scribendo hunc librum compleuerunt mense Ianuariij
                        anno domine Millesimo CCCCmolxxvjto quo tempore dictus
                        Galfridus quasi quinquaginta et dictus Thomas quasi sexdecim etatis
                        extiterunt annorum’. The Parson’s Prologue ends on f.
                        89v; the Canon’s Yeoman’s Tale ends on f. 115
                    with: And þere a poynte for ended is my taleGod sende euery true
                        man bote of hise bale.

Holkham667.First Lines:
Was risen and romed in a chambre in highIn which he alle the noble
                    citee sigh…
Holkham667.Last Lines:
…That of his mercy god soo merciableOn vs his grete mercy
                    multeply
Holkham667.Note: Contains I.1065-VII.1479. Verse ends on f. 81vb.
Holkham667.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Clerk’s Tale, a Six-Text Print from 6 MSS not containing the
                Pardoner’s Tale.
The Chaucer Society
         Series 1, no. 92. London: Trübner, 1899.

Lichfield29.First Lines:
…With hym ther was his sone a ȝong squierA louier a
                    lusty bacheler…
Lichfield29.Last Lines:
…Beþ fructuous and þat in litel spaceAnd to do wel
                    god sende ȝou his grace
Lichfield29.Note:
Begins I.79; verse ends f. 255; prose ends f.
                    292v.
Lichfield29.Attributed Author:
…compiled by Geffray Chaucers of whoos soule Ihesu crist haue mercy
                    Amen (f. 292v)
Lichfield29.Attributed Title:
Here endeth the boke of the tales of Canterbery compiled by Geffray
                    Chaucers of whoos soule Ihesu crist haue mercy Amen (f.
                    293v)

Lincoln110.First Lines:
…And pouder marchaunt tart and gallyngaleWel coude he knowe a
                    drauȝt of londoun aleHe coude roste and sethe & boyle &
                    friȝeMake mortrews and well bake a pie…
Lincoln110.Last Lines:
…Beþ fructuous & þat in litil spaceAnd to do wel
                    god sende ȝow his grace
Lincoln110.Note:
I.381-X.639; original scribe ends f. 258v mid-way through
                        Parson’s Tale and remaining text (ff. 259-266v)
                    supplied by a hand of sixteenth century.

LonPhys388.First Lines:
Whanne that Aprill with his showris sooteThe drought of marche hath
                    perced the Roote…
LonPhys388.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and that in litil spaceAnd to do wele god
                    sende yow his grace
LonPhys388.Note:
Verse ends on f. 320v. Parson’s Tale ends X.1062 on f.
                        358v.

RylandsEng63.First Lines:
I have a wyfe parde as wel as thowyit nold I nat for the Oxen in my
                    plowe…
RylandsEng63.Last Lines:
…Ne clepe ne cry but be in his preyerffor it is Goddis hest
                    leve and dere
RylandsEng63.Note:
An 11-folio fragment: this leaf containing VIII.1091-167 of the
                        Canon’s Yeoman’s Tale. Part of the same MS as Manchester,  John Rylands Library Eng. 63 (‘Oxford Fragments’).

RylandsEng113.First Lines:
Whan þat Aprill with his shoures swoteÞe drowth of Marche
                    hath perced to þe roteAnd bathed euery vayne with soche
                        vertu licourOf which vertue engendred is þe
                    flour…
RylandsEng113.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and þat in litle spaceAnd to do wel god
                    send you his grace
RylandsEng113.Note:
Verse ends 171v. On f. 194 is the scribal colophon
                        ‘Iste liber Constat Johanni Brode Juniori’.

Petworth7.First Lines:
Whan that aprille with his shoures sooteThe drouht of marche hath
                    perced to þe roote…
Petworth7.Last Lines:
…Beeþ fructuous and þat in litel spaceAnd to do wel
                    god sende ȝow his grace
Petworth7.Attributed Title:
Here endeþ þe boke of þe talys of Caunterbury compiled / by
                    Geffray Chawcer on whoos soule Ihesu crist haue mercy / Amen (f.
                    307v)

Austin46.First Lines:
And þanne shal al this gold departed beeMy deere freend
                    bitwixe me and thee…
Austin46.Last Lines:
…And therfore herkeneth what þat I shal seyeAnd lat me
                    tellen al my tale I preye
Austin46.Note:
Part (a) = Lines VI.831-968 and VII.1-1353; Part (b) = Lines X.587-1092.
                    Part (a) signed ‘vj-viiij’; Part (b) signed
                    ‘ffj-ffiij’.

Austin143.First Lines:
…Her mouthe full small and therto softe and redeBut sikirly
                    she had a faire forehede…
Austin143.Last Lines:
…Byth ffructuous and þat in lytyll spaceAnd to do well
                    god send you his grace

ChicagoUL564.First Lines:
…Ne at his tale sawe I no man hym greueBut hit were only
                    oswalt þe Reue…
ChicagoUL564.Last Lines:
…I wylt ȝow shewe & ȝif ȝow luste to leerI
                    wyl ȝow teche pleynly þe mateer
ChicagoUL564.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Clerk’s Tale, a Six-Text Print from 6 MSS not containing the
                Pardoner’s Tale.
The Chaucer Society
         Series 1, no. 92. London: Trübner, 1899.

Plimpton253.First Lines:
…Ey god mercy sayde our oste thoNow suche awyff y pray god
                    kepe me fro…
Plimpton253.Last Lines:
…To make his iapes and his wrechednesOf whiche a substiciens
                    cursidnes…
Plimpton253.Note:
f. 1: Epilogue to the Merchant’s Tale (IV.2419-2440),
                    followed by V.1-8 (adapted for the Franklin rather than the Squire); V.709-752
                    of Franklin’s Tale; fol. 2: V.1198-1272.

Digital Scriptorium: Facsimile of Plimpton MS 253.
         Columbia University, 1996-.

PierpontM249.First Lines:
Whan that April with […]The droughte of Marche had perced to
                    […]
PierpontM249.Last Lines:
…Both fructuous and that in lytel spaceAnd to do wel god sende
                    you his grace
PierpontM249.Note: Ends at X.1013. Verse ends on f. 245.

PhilRos10841.First Lines:
Vn to þe straunge lordes as it was RyghtNe ther was holden no
                    discomfortureffor fallyng is an vn auenture…
PhilRos10841.Last Lines:
…Hath not lucres y sleyn hirself allasAt rome ther sche
                    oppressed was
PhilRos10841.Note:
Contains I.2718-X.917. Verse ends on f. 191v at VI.1406 with
                    the catchwords ‘Of Tarquyne.’

PhilRos10842.First Lines:
Wich that I help my fadir for to steleAnd good lemman God the save
                    and keep…
PhilRos10842.Last Lines:
…Was nat made there but it was made to foreAnd othir thingis
                    wich I shall tell more
PhilRos10842.Note:
An 11-folio fragment: I.4246-4372 of the Reeve’s Tale,
                        Cook’s Prologue, and Cook’s Tale; II.95-140,
                    211-350, 1051-1120 of the Man of Law’s Tale; V.57-132 of the
                        Squire’s Tale; VIII.1091-1167 of the Canon’s
                        Yeoman’s Tale; VII.836-922 of the Tale of Thopas and the
                    Thopas-Melibee Link; X.256-297, 1043-1073 of the Parson’s Tale.
                    Part of the same MS as Manchester,  John Rylands Library Eng. 63 (‘Oxford Fragments’).

PUL100.First Lines:
…ffirst on þe wal was peyntid a forestIn wich there
                    dwellith nethir man ne best…
PUL100.Last Lines:
…Beth fructuous and þat in litil spaseAnd for to do wel
                    God send vs grace
PUL100.Note: Contains I.1975-X.754. Verse ends on f. 203.

BNangl39.First Lines:
Whan that april with his shoureȝ swoteþe drought of March
                    haþ percyd to þe rote…
BNangl39.Last Lines:
…Where so thou come amongis hy or lowekepe wel thi tung and
                    thenk vppon þe croweExplicit fabula mancipij et
                    cetera
BNangl39.Note:
A ‘U’ lombard initial precedes the first word of the text,
                    ‘Whan’. On fol. 83v is a scribal colophon: ‘a
                        elle magre xij xij quod  Duxworth scriptor xij’.

TokyoTak22.First Lines:
SIr Clerk of Oxinford owre Oste saydeȝe ryden as style and coy
                    as doth a maydeWere newe spowsyd syttyng at a bordeThis day ne herde I
                    of your mouth a worde…
TokyoTak22.Last Lines:
…And Johnkyn hath I wonne a newe gownemy tale is done and we
                    be nygh at towneSyr clerk of Oxynford oure ost seyde
TokyoTak22.Note:
Extracts from the Canterbury Tales: Clerk’s Prologue
                    (ff. 1-2); Clerk’s Tale (ff. 2v-29); ‘Lenvoye de
                    Chau[n]cer’ (ff. 29-30); Wife of Bath’s Prologue (ff.
                        30-47v); Wife of Bath’s Tale (ff. 48-56);
                        Friar’s Prologue (ff. 56v-57); Friar’s
                        Tale (ff. 57r-64v); Summoner’s Prologue (ff.
                        64v-65v); Summoner’s Tale (ff.
                        65v-77v).
TokyoTak22.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Clerk’s Tale, a Six-Text Print from 6 MSS not containing the
                Pardoner’s Tale.

         Series 1, no. 92. London: Trübner, 1899.

Whan that aprille with his shoures sooteThe drouȝte of Marche
                    hath persed the roote…

TokyoTak32.First Lines:
…He yaf nowt of the text a pulled henThat seyht that hvnteris
                    be noun holy men…
TokyoTak32.Last Lines:
…Beht fructuous and that in lytell spaceAnd to doon weell god
                    sende yow of his grace
